entry.title: Topological Quantum Field Theory
entry.summary:
In general, a good source to stay up to date is https://sites.google.com/ucdavis.edu/quantumalgebragroup/

Meeting Notes

11/07/2022

  • TQFTs to TQCs

entry.content:
In general, a good source to stay up to date is https://sites.google.com/ucdavis.edu/quantumalgebragroup/

Meeting Notes

11/07/2022

  • TQFTs to TQCs

Something I was happy to learn in this meeting was the definition of a TQFT. First we define a cobordism between manifolds $\Sigma_0$ and $\Sigma_1$ which is a compact manifold $M$ such that $\partial M = \Sigma_0 \sqcup \Sigma_1$. Then we have a category of cobordisms which we'll denote $\text{Cob}(d)$ which are $d$-dimensional orientable cobordisms. Note that the dimension of the cobordisms is $+1$ dimension of the cobordant manifolds.

  • The objects are $d$ dimensional, smooth, oriented, and closed manifolds.
  • Morphisms are cobordisms (so $d+1$ dimensional manifolds) $M$ with $\partial M: \Sigma_0 \to \Sigma_1$. $M$ is a morphism $M : \Sigma_0 \to \Sigma_1$.

Now if $\mathbb{K}$ is a field, a $(2+1)$ dimensional TQFT is an $\otimes$-Functor $Z: \text{Cob}(d) \to \text{Vec}(\mathbb{K})$.

This definition sets up some other nice things, like allowing us to call a TQFT Hermitian ($Z(-M) = Z(M)^*$ for $\mathbb{K} = \mathbb{C}$) and unitarity such that $Z(\Sigma)$ is a Hilbert space.

Somewhat unrelated we discussed anyons which are important because non-abelian anyons can be used in the contruction of a topological quantum computer (Kitaev, Freedman, Larsen, Wang). Abelian anyons seemed simple enough to define. For operators $T_1, T_2$ we have that $[T_1, T_2] = e^{i \theta}$. This means if we exchange the states of two (abelian) anyons then the state of the joint system only changes by some phase. I may write about this more either in future meetings notes or a modification of this one.

entry.title: Quantum Complexity reading group (started 10/2022)
entry.summary:
Background

This reading group was started by Sanchayan Dutta to study complexity theory. Ultimately, we seek to gain a background in the quantum PCP conjecture. Each week various members of the reading group give a short presentation based on research, what we encounter in the notes, or related topics of …
entry.content:
Background

This reading group was started by Sanchayan Dutta to study complexity theory. Ultimately, we seek to gain a background in the quantum PCP conjecture. Each week various members of the reading group give a short presentation based on research, what we encounter in the notes, or related topics of interest. Slides from presentations will be uploaded when available and I'll link to some things which were interesting to me that I plan to go back and read about should I stop procrastinating.

Resources

Advanced Topics in Quantum Information Theory
Toby Cubitt's Advanced Quantum Information theory
Aaronson's Lecture Notes

Slides

Here are the slides from some of the talks given by members in the group.

  • Hamiltonian Complexity Part 1
  • Classical complexity reductions
  • Hamiltonian Complexity Part 2
  • Local Hamiltonian Problem (Part1)
  • Advice, Oracle Separation, QMA & QCMA
  • BQP/qpoly $\subseteq$ PP/poly

Some interesting things mentioned to wiki

  • Weingarten calculus
  • Kitaev-Feynman clock
  • Transverse field Ising model
  • Simulating quantum TMs
  • Bethe ansatz
  • Group non-membership problem

Future topics I plan on giving talks for

  • [x] Classical complexity reductions
  • [x] Quantum advice & quantum oracles
  • [ ] Quantum circuit complexity
  • [x] BQP/qpoly $\subseteq$ PostBQP/poly $=$ PP/poly
  • [ ] Results on the Solovay-Kitaev theorem
